Authors: Agnihotri, Sabrina; Park, Caroline; Jones, Roland; Goodman, Deborah; Patel, Mitesh
Article Title: Defining and measuring indicators of successful transitions for youth aging out of child welfare systems: A scoping review and narrative synthesis
Abstract: Youth aging out of child welfare systems face an abrupt transition to adulthood and expectation for self-sufficiency with few supports. The current study represents a scoping review and narrative synthesis that sought to identify indicators used to measure the success of aging out youth and their corresponding methods of assessment. A database search was conducted and 150 articles were included in the review. Results revealed eight broad indicators of successful transitions, including: education, employment, basic needs, social support and relationships, conduct and victimization, health, general living skills, and resilience and psychological empowerment. As a larger category, health was broken down into five subdomains of physical, mental health symptoms, reproductive/sexual health, substance use, and access to care/service utilization. Findings highlight the need for comprehensive tools and strengths-based approaches to assessing transitional gaps earlier in the aging out process. Given the interdependency of indicator outcomes, fulsome measurement can provide a window into a youth's future concerns.

llama-3.2-3b-instruct.reason: The study design is a scoping review and narrative synthesis, which does not meet the inclusion criteria of a meta-analysis, systematic review of controlled trials, RCTs (including cluster RCTs), or quasi-experimental studies with a control group.

qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.reason: The study does not address employment policies for people with mental health disorders. It focuses on indicators of successful transitions for youth aging out of child welfare systems.

phi-3-mini-4k-instruct.reason: The study focuses on youth aging out of child welfare systems, not specifically on people with mental health disorders.

mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501.reason: The study does not focus on people with mental health disorders and does not directly address employment interventions.
